bestBHT.bht: Jesus made it clear who should follow Him and instructed others to give place in order to emphasize the sequence of events. When Jesus suffered no man to go in, He specifically referred to the room where the dead body was located. Only Peter, James, and John, His chosen ones, were permitted to witness the miracle. Even the parents of the young girl were granted access, highlighting the selectiveness of this important moment.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 8:51, Jesus gave clear instructions to the onlookers, declaring who were to follow Him and commanding others to give place. This was not an attempt to harmonize different accounts, but to emphasize the sequence of events. It is important to understand that when Jesus suffered no man to go in, He was referring to the room where the dead body lay. He chose to only allow Peter, James, and John, who were His favored ones, to witness the miracle. Even the parents of the maiden were admitted, demonstrating the exclusivity of this moment.

In this passage, Jesus gave instructions and declared who were to follow Him, urging others to give place. This was not an attempt to harmonize accounts, but to highlight the sequence of events. Jesus deliberately limited access to the room where the dead body lay, only allowing Peter, James, and John to witness the miracle. Even the parents of the maiden were admitted, underscoring the exclusivity of this significant moment.

Jesus made it clear who should follow Him and instructed others to give place in Luke 8:51. This serves to emphasize the sequence of events, rather than trying to harmonize different accounts. When Jesus suffered no man to go in, He specifically referred to the room where the dead body was located. Only Peter, James, and John, His chosen ones, were permitted to witness the miracle. Even the parents of the young girl were granted access, highlighting the selectiveness of this important moment.

Jesus made it clear who should follow Him and instructed others to give place in order to emphasize the sequence of events. When Jesus suffered no man to go in, He specifically referred to the room where the dead body was located. Only Peter, James, and John, His chosen ones, were permitted to witness the miracle. Even the parents of the young girl were granted access, highlighting the selectiveness of this important moment.

In Luke 8:51, Jesus declared who were to follow Him and commanded others to give place. His intention was not to harmonize accounts but to highlight the sequence of events. When Jesus suffered no man to go in, He meant that no one was allowed to enter the room where the dead body lay. Only Peter, James, and John, His favored ones, were privileged to witness the miracle. This exclusive access extended even to the parents of the young girl.
